column4: The numbers placed at the beginning of a composition. The upper number indicates the number of beats per measure; the lower number tells what kind of a note with receive one beat

A curved line that connects the heads of two notes together to create a longer sound (equal to both added together)
The first note on the treble clef staff; a common starting note for many melodies and often used to create tension.
This note is often used to add energy to music.
This note is often used to create a sense of resolution. This can be heard in the song Fur Elise" by Beethoven.
This note is often used to create tension such as in "I Will Always Love You" by Whitney Houston. In this the melody rises to an F4 note on the word "love" in the phrase "and I will always love you."
This note is often used to add movement to music.
This note is a common starting note for many melodies and often used to create a sense of resolution.

This note is often used to add energy to music. This can be heard in "Don't Stop Believin'" by Journey where the melody rises to a B4 note on the word "believin'" in the phrase "don't stop believin'.".

This note is one octave higher than middle C and is often used to create tension. This can be heard in the song "Creep" by Radiohead. In the chorus of the song the melody rises to a C5 note on the word "creep" in the phrase "I'm a creep." This note is higher than any note in the preceding melody and creates a sense of tension and unease.
This note is often used to add movement to music. This can be heard in the song "Hallelujah" by Leonard Cohen where the melody rises to a D5 note on the word "Hallelujah."
This note is often used to create a sense of resolution.
This note is on the second ledger line above the treble clef staff and is often used to create tension.
This note is often used to add movement to music. This can be heard in "Let it Be" by The Beatles where the melody rises to a G5 note on the word "be" in the phrase "let it be."
This is the lowest F on the bass clef and is often used to create a deep and rich bass sound.
The next note up from F2. G2 is often used to add movement and energy to bass lines.
This note is a whole step above G2 and is a common starting note for many bass lines and melodies.
This note is a common starting note for many bass lines and is often used to add depth and complexity to music.
The first note on the bass clef staff; C3 is often used to create tension.
This note is a whole step above C3 and is often used to add movement and energy to bass lines.
This note is often used to create a sense of resolution or finality.
The first note on the bass clef ledger line above the staff; F3 is often used to create tension.
This note is a whole step above F3 and is often used to add movement and energy to bass lines.
This note is often used to create a sense of resolution or finality.
This note is often used to add depth and complexity to music.
The first ledger line above the bass clef staff; also known as middle C.
